CO2 methanation is an essential means of utilizing CO2, which is crucial to solving environmental problems and alleviating energy crisis. The design and development of high- performance low temperature CO2 methanation catalysts is the key to its further application. In this work, the metal-support interaction of Ni/CeO2 catalyst was regulated by changing the calcination temperature and Ni loadings to optimize the CO2 methanation performance. The results showed that 5NiCe-800 exhibited the best CO2 conversion of 83.1 % and 98.0 % CH4 selectivity at 350 °C, since it has a suitable Ni-CeO2 interaction, higher oxygen vacancy concentration, great reducibility and better basic site distribution. The reaction mechanism and the synergistic effect of CeO2 and Ni in CO2 methanation was revealed by in-situ FTIR, which is of great significance for the development of efficient CeO2 supported Ni-based for CO2 methanation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni/CeO2 Hydrogenation CO2 methanation Metal-support interactions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 concentration in air has been 50 % higher than that before the Industrial Revolution due to human activities, leading to a series of environmental problems. In order to actively respond to these problems, efforts are made to achieve a global temperature rise of no more than 1.5 °C by the end of the 21st century [1]. Among them, hydrogenation of CO2 to yield fuels and long-chain compounds plays a vital role in achieving carbon neutrality thanks to the booming of renewable hydrogen. And the supported nickel catalysts have a good application prospect in catalyzing CO2 hydrogenation since their relative low cost, the availability, good activity and high methane selectivity [2]. The geometry and electronic structure at the interface of supported mental catalysts have important effects on the reactivity, and the Metal–Support Interactions (MSI) is an effective means of modulating the metal- support interface [3]. Usually, such MSI formed at the metal- support interface undergoes electron transfer between support and metal, diffusion of substances at the interface and H2 and/or O2 overflow. An appropriate MSI can stabilize the active phase metal, improve the reduction of the metal oxide, obtain a large active metal area, and promote the reacting molecules to adsorb and activate [4–6]. For example, Alexander et al. [7] found that when CoO/CZ catalysts had suitable CoO-CZ forces, O2 overflow occurred at the metal interface, greatly improving the CO bond breaking ability and promoting CO2 hydrogenation to CH4. In addition, Strong Metal-Support Interactions (SMSI) is usually more favorable for CC formation than CH formation [8]. As reported in the literature, TiO2 semi-encapsulated Ni species were obtained by adjusting the reduction temperature of TiO2-x/Ni catalysts, and the SMSI formed at the Niδ−/TiO2− x interface improved the dissociation ability and C-chain growth of CO [9]. It is not difficult to find that the active metal-support interface is more likely to form on loaded catalysts with reduced supports, due to the large electronegativity of Si in inert supports(e.g. SiO2 and C), which is more likely to form strong interactions with Ni [10]. The strong interaction between Ni and SiO2 generates nickel silicate, which is difficult to reduce and has a relatively poor selectivity for CH4 [11]. In addition, CeO2 has the ability to store and release oxygen, attributed to its low redox potential of Ce4+/Ce3+ [12,13]. Ceria-supported Ni catalysts can interact with more CO2 species than other supports, leading to great activity of CO2 methanation [14]. Therefore, CeO2-loaded Ni catalysts were chosen for this work and the low temperature CH4 selectivity and activity of the catalyst were improved by designing and optimizing the interfacial properties between Ni and CeO2. The metal-support interactions can be modulated by adjusting the geometry of the metal nanoparticles or the support CeO2 [7,15], the morphological characteristics [15,14] and the chemical composition of the support CeO2 [16,17]. It is also possible to adjust the calcination conditions of Ni/CeO2 catalysts, such as the reduction temperature [18], calcination atmosphere [19] or reduction-oxidation cycles [20] to obtain. However, there are relatively few studies in the literature on the regulation of metal-support interaction by calcination temperature. It is generally believed that air calcination of catalysts tends to cause the agglomeration and growth of metal ions, which results that the stability of the catalyst is decreased [20,21]. However, it is reported in recent studies that high temperature calcination of catalysts can promote the uniform dispersion of metal particles on the surface of transition metal supports, resulting in better activity and stability of catalysts [22,23]. Moreover, metal loading influences the Ni dispersion, which in turn affects the interactions between metal and support [24]. For supported nickel catalysts, there exists an optimal amount of nickel to obtain excellent catalyst performance, depending on the interaction with the support [25]. Zhang et al. [26] have studied the effect of Ni loading (2.5–50 wt.%) on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, which shown that the catalyst with the Ni loading about 25 % achieved the best performance on methanation. Nevertheless, high Ni loading causes the agglomeration of Ni and poor reduction degree of NiO. Italiano et al. [24] studied the effect of Ni loading (7–35 wt.%) on Y2O3 for CO2 methanation. They have shown that CO2 methanation rates per unit mass of Ni decreased by increasing the Ni loading. Therefore, we adjust the metal-support interaction by varying air calcination temperatures and the Ni loadings to construct Ni-Ce interfaces with abundant active sites for CO2 methanation reaction. In addition, the mechanism of the reaction was further studied. This work is a guideline for tuning the NiCe interface to obtain high performance catalysts for CO2 methanation reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The preparation of CeO2 was as follows. First, the solution was prepared with 96 g NaOH and 500 ml deionized water, followed by the dissolution of 8.648 g Ce(NO3)3-6H2O. The mixed solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, then transferred to a 500 mL hydrothermal reactor and kept at 100 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the reactor then cooled naturally to room temperature, and the content was filtered and washed with deionized water until pH = 7 to obtain filter cake. Rod-like CeO2 was prepared by drying the cake in the oven at 80 °C for 12 h and grinding and roasting at 300 °C for 3 h. The isovolume impregnation method was used to prepare the CeO2-loaded Ni catalysts as follows. Different concentrations were obtained by adding different amounts of Ni(NO3)2-6H2O to deionized water. And then the prepared solutions were added to 1 g CeO2 drop by drop. Subsequently, the mixture was sonicated for 1 h and then placed at room temperature for 12 h. The mixture obtained at the same concentration was calcined at 300 °C, 600 °C and 800 °C for 3 h to obtain a catalyst labeled 5NiCe-T, T = 300 °C, 600 °C and 800 °C. The mixture obtained at different concentrations was calcined at 800 °C for 3 h to obtain a catalyst labeled xNiCe-800, where x is the Ni loading (wt.%), x = 2,5,10,15. 2.2 Catalyst characterization All samples were degassed before analysis and kept at 300 °C vacuum for 4 h to remove water and impurities. Afterward, N2 adsorption–desorption measurements were performed on TriStar 3000 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). All catalysts were tested by X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) using the X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) and the Cu Kα radiation (c = 1.54056 Å) was obtained. The scanned 2θ angle was from 10° to 80° at the scan rate of 8°/min. The InVia-Reflex (Renishaw, England) spectrometer was used to obtain Raman spectrums with a 532 nm emission light source. The micromorphology of the catalyst was analyzed with emission scanning electron microscope S4800 (Hitachi, Japan). The element distribution in the powder was performed by Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDS). The AutoChem 2910 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) was used for H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Before the examination, 50 mg (20–40 mesh) fresh samples were treated at 200 °C argon for 1 h. The samples were then heated to 750 °C at the rate of 10 °C /min at a flow of 10 % H2/Ar. The AutoChem 2910 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) was also used on CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) characterizations. In order to obtain the clean surfaces, fresh catalysts were first heated to 200 °C and kept for 1 h under Ar atmosphere. And these catalysts were reduced under hydrogen flow of 30 mL/min at 400 °C for 1 h. After reduction, the reduced sample was kept under CO2 atmosphere for 30 min to saturate with CO2, then using Ar flow to purge the sample for 30 min, and ramping up to 450 °C at the rate of 10 °C /min. In-situ Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (In-situ FTIR) were carried out on the Nicolet 6700 infrared spectrometer, and the reaction intermediates were detected by micro-transient response integration system. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The CO2 hydrogenation performance of samples was tested at 250–450 °C under atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with an inner diameter (I.D.) of 8 mm. In detail, 0.2 g fresh catalyst (20–40 mesh) mixed with 0.4 g quartz sand (40–60 mesh) was placed into the reactor. Then, the mixture was in-situ reduced at 400 °C using H2 (30 mL/min) together with N2 (30 mL/min) for 2 h. Afterward, the mixtures of H2, CO2 and He (with a molar ratio of 4:1:1) were fed into the reactor with the flow rate of 150 mL/min. The reaction was held for 30 min and then analyzed at each temperature. Using a cold trap to collected water vapor produced during the reaction. The gas chromatograph (Agilent 4890D) was used to analyze other products quantitatively. The conversion of CO2, and the selectivity of CH4 and CO, and carbon balance as well as the reaction rate of CO2 were calculated by using the following formula: X C O 2 ( % ) = F ( CO 2 ) in − F ( CO 2 ) out F ( CO 2 ) in × 100 % S CH 4 ( % ) = F ( C H 4 ) out F ( CO 2 ) in − F ( CO 2 ) out × 100 % S CO ( % ) = F ( CO ) out F ( CO 2 ) in − F ( CO 2 ) out × 100 % R C O 2 = F ( CO 2 ) in × X C O 2 n C B ( % ) = [ 1 − F ( CO 2 ) out + F ( C H 4 ) out + F ( CO ) out F ( CO 2 ) in ] × 100 % where X C O 2 denotes CO2 conversion; S(CH4) and S(CO) represent the selectivity of CH4 and CO; Fout and Fin represent the molar flow rate of outlet and inlet (mol/min); R C O 2 refers to the reaction rate of CO2; n indicates the absolute molar amount of nickel; CB indicates carbon balance. And all tests have carbon balance within ±3 %, indicating the reliability of the results. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of calcination temperature on the 5NiCe-T catalysts 3.1.1 Morphology and structures The catalysts calcinated at different temperatures with the same loading were examined and firstly characterized for N2 physisorption, as shown in Fig. 1 . All of the catalysts exhibited similar isotherms attributed to the IUPAC-defined Class IV adsorption-desorption isotherm as well as a clear H3-type hysteresis loop [27]. In addition, the appearance of hysteresis loop at high relative pressure (p/p0 > 0.8) was indicative of a broad pore size distribution, containing slit-shaped pores in the structure [28]. Fig. 1(b) shows that the pore size distribution of the catalyst mainly concentrated in the range of 10–30 nm, indicating the presence of stacked pore channels and mesoporous in the catalyst. The structural information of these catalysts is presented in Table 1 , which showed that the specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the catalyst after calcination at different temperatures change little, indicating that the calcination temperature does not cause large differences in the weaving properties of the catalysts. The physical phase analysis of the 5NiCe-T catalysts was performed, and the results are plotted in Fig. 2 . All catalysts exhibit characteristic diffraction peaks of CeO2 attributed to the cubic fluorite structure, and the diffraction peaks located at 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7° and 79.1° correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal planes respectively (JCPDS 34-0394). With the increase of calcination temperature, the intensity of CeO2 diffraction peaks in the catalysts was significantly enhanced. The average CeO2 crystallite size was calculated by the Scherrer equation, according to the characteristic diffraction peaks of the CeO2 (111) crystal facets. As show in Table 1, the higher calcination temperature makes the particles in the catalysts grow. However, no obvious characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to NiO (JCPDS No. 47-1409) were observed even at calcination temperatures up to 800 °C. This result indicates that the NiO particles are highly dispersed on the 5NiCe-T catalyst (particles less than 5 nm) or Ni2+ is doped into the lattice of CeO2. Therefore, there is a strong interaction between NiO and CeO2, which is conducive to improving the activity of the catalyst [29,30]. To further observe the morphological characteristics and exposed crystalline surfaces of the catalysts, the reduced catalysts were characterized by TEM and high-resolution electron microscopy HRTEM, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3(d) shows the rod-like structure of the carrier CeO2, indicating that the desired carrier morphology was successfully obtained by calcined at 300 °C. These rod-like structures of CeO2 are approximately 10 nm wide and 80 nm long. similarly, the reduced 5NiCe-T catalyst also exhibits a distinct rod-like structure of CeO2, and no significant agglomeration was observed in the catalyst. Ni particles were further observed as shown in Fig. 3(a1), (b1) and (c1). Apparently, the crystal plane spacing of 0.21 nm and 0.31 nm are attributed to the Ni(111) crystal plane and CeO2(111) crystal plane, respectively [31]. In addition, spherical Ni particles were presented on rod-shaped CeO2, while an interface existed between Ni particles and CeO2 particles. Since the high temperature treatment may cause metal particles to agglomerate, and the reduction of the metal dispersion, EDS-mappings analysis was performed on catalyst 5NiCe-T to analyze the dispersion of Ni and Ce in the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3(e) and (f), Ni particles on the CeO2 support are well-dispersed without obvious agglomeration, which was consistent with the XRD analysis results. 3.1.2 Surface oxygen vacancy analysis A kind of key site for CO2 activation is oxygen vacancy, which is easily generated in NiCe catalysts. Raman spectra is an important way to measure the concentrations of oxygen vacancies, as shown in Fig. 4 . The characteristic peaks at wave numbers of 220 cm−1 and 450 cm−1 are respectively attributed to the second-order transverse acoustic mode 2TA and symmetric stretching vibration mode F2g for the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 [29,32]. From the figure, it is easy to find that the F2g peak become wider and has a tendency to red-shift for all catalysts compared to the pure support CeO2. Indicating that the addition of Ni2+ changes the lattice spacing and the bond length of CeO in CeO2, as well as forms the NiCe interaction [33,29]. The characteristic peak at wave number 550–600 cm−1 is attributed to the defect mode D in the catalyst [34], which can be further split-fitted to two different defective sites. Specifically, the defective site at 620 cm−1 is due to the conversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+ in the support, denoted as Di, and the defective site at 550 cm−1 is an external defect caused by the doping of external metal (Ni) into the carrier CeO2 lattice, denoted as De [34]. The ratio of the D mode peak area to the F2g mode peak area is usually used as a measure of the oxygen vacancy concentration [31]. Therefore, the individual peak areas were integrated to compare the catalyst oxygen vacancy concentration, and the results are listed in Table 2 . It is clear that the AD/AF2g values increase from 0.59 to 0.84 and ADe/AF2g values increase from 0.26 to 0.56 with increasing calcination temperature, while the ADi/AF2g values do not change significantly (in the range of 0.32–0.35). Indicating that the concentration of oxygen vacancy caused by doping increases with increasing calcination temperature, and further indicating the presence of some degree of metal-support interaction in the reduced catalyst. Therefore, the order of oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst is 5NiCe-800 > 5NiCe-600 > 5NiCe-300. To further clarify the oxygen vacancies concentration on the catalyst and the surface chemical state of the catalyst surface, the reduced 5NiCe-T catalysts were characterized by XPS, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that the XPS signal for Ni 2p over 5NiCe-300 and 5NiCe-500 was weak, with the 5NiCe-800 showing significant Ni 2p signals. The characteristic peaks at peaks at 852.3 eV and 855.4 eV respectively attributed to the signals of Ni0 and NiO [33,35-37]. NiO is caused by the partial oxidization of Ni metal on the surface during the operation process. In addition, the peaks in the binding energy range of 858–862 eV belong to the satellite peaks of Ni 2p3/2, signifying the presence of NiONiO bonding mode on the catalyst surface, indicating the presence of NiO clusters or nanoparticles in the catalyst [38]. Therefore, it is possible that hard-to-reduce Ni species exist in the form of NiOCe in 5NiCe-300 and 5NiCe-600 [33]. Fig. 5(b) shows the spectrum of Ce 3d. Since there are two valence states of Ce, 10 peaks can be obtained by fitting them to the split peaks, with “u” and “v” denoting the characteristic peaks of Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 orbitals, respectively. Specifically, the v (881.8),v″ (887.9 eV),v′″ (897.9 eV),u(900.5 eV),u″ (906.7 eV) and u′″ (916.3 eV is attributing to Ce4+ species, v0 (880.5 eV),v′ (884.3 eV),u0 (899.7 eV) and u′ (903.0 eV) is attributing to Ce3+ species [39,30]. The ratio of all Ce3+ peak area to the total Ce 3d peak area was used as an approximation to evaluate the Ce3+ concentration, which can be obtained for different catalysts. Since the presence of Ce3+ is always related to the oxygen vacancy concentration, the Ce3+ concentration can also be used as an index to evaluate the oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalysts, and the higher the concentration of Ce3+ indicates the higher oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalysts [20,40]. The values of Ce3+ concentrations are listed in Table 3 , and the oxygen vacancy concentrations are 34.7 %, 35.2 % and 36.6 % for 5NiCe-300, 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 respectively. To further calculate the oxygen vacancy concentration, we fitted the O 1s spectra with split peaks, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The characteristic peaks at 530.5 ± 0.3 eV, 532.4 ± 0.3 eV and 528.5 ± 0.3 eV are attributed to surface oxygen (Osur), adsorbed oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olatt) species, respectively [33]. Similarly, the ratio of the peak area of surface oxygen (Osur) species to the peak area of all oxygen species can be approximated as a measure of the oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst [40,33]. Table 3 lists the oxygen vacancy concentrations in the three catalysts, which are 35.4 %, 36.2 % and 42.5 % for 5NiCe-300, 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 respectively. Therefore, the concentration of oxygen vacancy in the catalyst increases with the increase of the calcination temperature. The oxygen vacancy concentrations calculated by different methods were compared, as shown in Fig. 5(d). It is clear that the Ce3+ concentration, Osur concentration and AD/AF2g results are consistent, so the 5NiCe-800 catalyst has more oxygen vacancy concentration in it. In addition, the peaks of O 1s gradually shifted to high binding energy with the increase of calcination temperature, which indicated that higher calcination temperature made the electron density of oxygen species decrease, probably due to the creation of more oxygen vacancies in the NiCe catalyst [41]. 3.1.3 Reducibility and surface basicity analysis In order to study the reducing properties of NiO and the metal-support interactions, H2-TPR characterization of the prepared support CeO2 and 5NiCe-T catalysts was carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . CeO2 exhibited three H2 consumption peaks at temperatures of 385 °C, 506 °C and 675 °C, which were put down to the H2 consumption by the adsorbed oxygen species on the support surface and the reduction of the CeO2 [40,38]. Fig. 6(b) shows the H2-TPR results for the 5NiCe-T catalysts, and it is clear that the reduction peaks of these catalysts are shifted toward lower temperatures compared to the pure support CeO2. 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 catalysts exhibit similar reduction peaks α, β and γ in the tested temperature range, indicating that these two catalysts have similar reduction behaviors. α peak may due to the reduction of the oxygen species adsorbed in oxygen vacancies and NiO at the NiOCe interface, which have a weaker interaction with the support NiOCe interface and can therefore be reduced at lower temperature [21,42,30]. The β peaks mainly originate from the consumption of H2 during the reduction of NiO to Ni0 in the catalyst. β1 at lower temperature belongs to the reduction of NiO in the NiOCe interface structure, while β2 at higher temperature belongs to the reduction of bulk NiO or NiO with strong interactions with CeO2 [31]. In addition, the γ peak is attributed to the support CeO2 surface being reduced [43]. Apparently, the H2 consumption peaks of 5NiCe-300 are all concentrated at 250 °C (α-peak) and show a weak β-peak, which may be caused by undecomposed nitrate species in the catalyst after lower temperature calcination. After calcination, most of the Ni monomers are in the form of nitrate, and this nitrate will be reduced to NiO and then reduced to Ni0 or directly reduced to Ni0 by H2 in the low temperature. This inference is also consistent with the results of Lin et al. [20]. In conclusion, the reduction peak temperature of the catalyst gradually increases with the calcination temperature increasing, which indicates that the increase of the calcination temperature enhances the interaction between Ni-CeO2. CO2-TPD was employed to determine the strength of basic sites to further investigate the surface properties of the 5NiCe-T catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . According to the literature, the basic sites on the catalyst surface can be classified into three types, which are weak basic sites located at about 100 °C (α), medium basic sites from 100 °C to 450 °C (β) and strong basic sites above 450 °C (γ) [44,45]. Among them, weak basic sites may come from the desorption of CO2 adsorbed on the support surface and the desorption of HCO3 − or HCO2 2− formed by CO2 adsorbed on OH groups, medium basic sites come from the desorption of biligomeric carbonates(b-CO3 2-) formed by CO2 adsorbed on metal-oxygen pairs, and strong basic sites are the desorption of monoligomeric carbonates (m-CO3 2−) or multiligomeric carbonates(p-CO3 2−) formed by CO2 adsorbed on O2− on the catalyst surface [41,46–48]. It is clear that all catalysts exhibit three basic sites: α, β and γ. As the calcination temperature increased, the peak area of the γ peak decreased rapidly, indicating that the calcination temperature greatly reduced the strong basic sites on the catalyst surface. Since the intermediates formed by CO2 on different basic sites have different reactivity, the contribution of different basic sites to methanation performance is different. Bian et al. [48] reported that the intermediate of CO2 methanation reaction on 5Ni/NRs catalyst with many strong basic sites may be linear CO, while that on 5Ni/NPs catalyst with abundant medium alkaline sites is surface carbonate, and the activity of the latter is much higher than that of the former. Therefore, the medium basic sites are more favorable than strong basic sites on CO2 methanation. In addition, Xie et al. [29] demonstrated that the stronger weak basic sites are the key to increased methanation activity in Ni/CeO2-nanorods catalysts. Yu et al. [49] demonstrated by CO2-TPSR that the CO2 methanation reaction on Ni/CeO2-SGM catalyst starts at 170 °C and the CH4 yield is negligible around 400 °C, so the weak and medium basic sites are more important for the reaction. Therefore, the 5NiCe-800 catalyst with fewer strong basic sites and abundant weak basic sites and medium basic sites can greatly improve CO2 methanation activity. 3.1.4 CO2 methanation performance on different 5NiCe-T catalysts The CO2 hydrogenation activity of the prepared 5NiCe-T catalysts with different calcination temperatures was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 8 . Apparently, CO2 conversion of all catalysts increased with increasing temperature, and the activity of CO2 hydrogenation starts to decrease at around 400 °C. In addition, the 5NiCe-T catalysts showed a large variation in activity at the low temperature stage, with the best reaction temperature of 350 °C for the 5NiCe-800 catalyst with 83.07 % CO2 conversion and 98 % CH4 selectivity, while the 5NiCe-600 catalyst performed best at 400 °C with 78 % CO2 conversion and 98 % CH4 selectivity. At 300 °C, the CO2 hydrogenation activity of 5NiCe-800 > 5NiCe-300 > 5NiCe-600. The main products of CO2 hydrogenation were CH4 and the by-product CO, and no other products were detected. Fig. 8(c) compares the reaction rates of different calcination temperature catalysts at around 280 °C. The 5NiCe-800 catalyst showed the best reaction rate of 11.87 molCO2 molNi −1 h−1. 3.2 Effect of Ni loading on the xNiCe-800 catalysts 3.2.1 Morphology and structures The catalysts calcinated at 800 °C with different loadings were examined and characterized for N2 physisorption. The isotherms and pore size distribution of xNiCe-800 catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . For all samples type IV with H3 hysteresis loop is observed. Similarly, the N2 adsorption on the catalysts occurred in the range of P/P 0 > 0.8, indicating that the catalysts are mostly macroporous structure internally. This is consistent with the relatively wide pore size distribution shown in Fig. 9(b), revealing the stacked pore channels and mesoporous structure of all catalysts. With the Ni loading increasing, the pore size distribution of the catalyst changed from bimodal to unimodal, mainly concentrated in the range of 10–40 nm. The physicochemical properties of these catalysts are summarized in Table 4 , which shows that with the increase of Ni loading, the specific surface area of xNiCe-800 catalyst presents a volcano-shaped trend, and 5NiCe-800 catalyst shows the largest pore volume (0.33 cm3/g) and specific surface area (79.7 m2/g). The X-ray diffraction patterns of fresh xNiCe-800 catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 (a). It can be seen that CeO2 attributed to the cubic fluorite structure is the main phase for all catalysts. The diffraction peaks intensity of CeO2 in the catalysts decrease significantly with the increase of Ni loading, which indicates that more NiO interact with CeO2 and inhibits the growth of CeO2 particles during high temperature treatment. In the meantime, obvious characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to NiO (JCPDS No. 47-1409) were observed in 10NiCe-800 and 15NiCe-800 catalysts, which indicated that the NiO crystallinity increases with the loading increasing [29]. The XRD patterns of the reduced xNiCe-800 catalysts are portrayed in Fig. 10(b). On the reduced catalysts, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni0 were difficult to observe. There is still no obvious characteristic peak of Ni0 in the slow sweep results of xNiCe-800 catalyst at 2θ = 26–30°, which indicates that a strong interaction between Ni and CeO2 is formed after H2 reduction treatment [50], promoting the high dispersion of Ni0 on the support. This highly dispersed Ni° can act as a site for activating H2, promoting the continuation of the reaction [51]. In addition, during the reduction process, Ni2+ may be doped into the CeO2 lattice to form an NiOCe at the interface, which contributes to activate CO2 [20]. TEM images of the reduced xNiCe-800 catalysts were shown in Fig. 11 . As presented in Fig. 11, all catalysts show the rod-like structure of the support CeO2, which indicated that the morphology of CeO2 unchanged during metal loading and calcination. Obviously, it can be seen that different catalysts show different degrees of agglomeration. In 2NiCe-800 and 5NiCe-800 catalyst, the agglomeration is less obvious. With the increase of Ni loading, more large Ni particles appear in 10NiCe-800 and 15NiCe-800. On the rod-like CeO2 surface, the 0.31 nm and 0.19 nm lattice fringes were well match with the CeO2 (111) and CeO2(110) facets are observed from the result of HRTEM. In addition, Ni particles in 2NiCe-800 maintain as ellipsoids, and most of them are embedded in CeO2 to form strong interaction with CeO2, while Ni particles in 5NiCe-800 and 10NiCe-800 maintain as hemispheres and an interface exists between Ni particles and CeO2. When the Ni loading increases, the Ni particles in 15NiCe-800 pile together, presenting blocky, and the phase interface area between CeO2 was further reduced. The interface between Ni-CeO2 produces abundant reactive oxygen species, which can improve CO2 activation capability, thus enhancing CO2 methanation activity at low temperatures. As reported in literature, during H2 reduction, Ni and CeO2 may form different degrees Ni-CeO2 interactions. Only when proper interaction forms, NiO is easy to be reduced and more active Ni sites are obtained to activate H2 [15]. In order to clarify the Ni mental dispersion, EDS-mappings analysis was performed on xNiCe-800 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12 . It can be seen that the dispersion of metallic Ni on the CeO2 support is good. 3.2.2 Surface oxygen vacancy analysis Raman spectroscopy was used to monitor oxygen vacancy concentration, as shown in Fig. 13 . The individual peak areas were integrated to compare the catalyst oxygen vacancy concentration, and the results are shown in Table 5 and Fig. 13(b). It is clear that ADi/AF2g values do not change significantly (in the range of 0.31–0.32), while the AD/AF2g and AD/AF2g values show volcano-shaped trend with different Ni loadings. The results indicate that Ni loading will affect the oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst, and this oxygen vacancy defect is mainly due to the doping of the external metal (Ni) into the support CeO2 lattice, which further indicating the formation of Ni-CeO2 interaction in reduced catalysts. Therefore, the order of oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst is 5NiCe-800 > 10NiCe-800 ≈ 15NiCe-800 > 2NiCe-800. The surface chemical states and elemental compositions of xNiCe-800 catalysts were studied by XPS analysis. Ni 2p, O 1s and Ce 3d spectra of these catalysts are shown in Fig. 14 . Compared with 5NiCe-T catalyst, xNiCe-800 catalysts showed obvious Ni 2p signal, which indicated that the NiO in xNiCe-800 catalyst was easier to reduce. The signal of Ni 2p3/2 was further split-fitted with peaks at 852.3 ± 0.2 eV, 853.7 ± 0.2 eV and 856.9 ± 0.3 eV attributed to the signals of Ni0, Ni2+ and NiOCe. Obviously, NiOCe was formed in the catalyst by H2 reduction treatment, because some Ni2+ may be doped into the lattice of CeO2 to form a strong Ni-CeO2 interaction [21]. The binding energies of NiOCe significantly decreased with increasing Ni loading, which indicates that electron transfer occurs between Ni and CeO2 during the reduction process, resulting in an electron-rich state of Ni0. As reported in literature, the electron transfer phenomenon occurs at the NiOCe phase interfaces [35]. There are abundant oxygen vacancies on the NiOCe interface, which can activate CO2 and promote the reaction. Fig. 14(b) shows the spectrum of Ce 3d. Similarly, there are two valence states of Ce, and 10 peaks can be obtained by fitting them to the split peaks. The values of Ce3+ concentration are listed in Table 6 , and the oxygen vacancy concentrations are 2NiCe-800 (24.7 %), 5NiCe-800 (36.6 %),10NiCe-800 (27.9 %) and 15NiCe-800 (24.9 %), thus, the catalyst has the highest oxygen vacancy concentration when the Ni loading is 5 wt.%. For O 1s spectra of the catalysts, three distinct peaks are observed in Fig. 14(c). Table 6 lists the oxygen vacancy concentrations for the catalysts, which is 31.2 %, 42.5 %, 37.6 % and 38.5 % for 2NiCe-800, 5NiCe-800, 10NiCe-800 and 15NiCe-800 respectively. As shown in Fig. 14(d), the 5 wt.% Ni catalyst has the highest oxygen vacancy concentration. 3.2.3 Reducibility and surface basicity analysis The H2-TPR experiments were carried out to reveal the reducibility of NiO and the metal-support interaction of xNiCe-800 catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 15 There are three fitted reduction peaks in the H2-TPR spectra of all catalysts, namely α peak at 200–300 °C, β peak at 350 °C-500 °C, and γ peak greater than 650 °C. The α peak mainly originates from the reduction of NiO and oxygen species at the NiOCe interface [49], which is consistent with the characterization results of XPS. The β peaks mainly originate from the consumption of H2 during the reduction of NiO to Ni0 in the catalyst. Two peaks β1 and β2 were shown in the range of 350–500 °C, indicating that there are two kinds of NiO with different interaction forces with the support in the Ni-based catalyst supported by rod-like CeO2, which is similar to the results of Thapanee et al. [52]. In addition, the γ peak is attributed to the support CeO2 surface being reduced [43]. Fig. 15(a)–(d) show the peak shape fitting results for each catalyst, and the temperature of each peak is compared, as shown in Fig. 15(e). Obviously, the position of each peak in different catalysts is basically the same, that is, the surface adsorbed oxygen and NiO in each catalyst are in a similar electron density. The area of β1 peak and β2 peak gradually increased with the increase of Ni loading, indicating that the increase of Ni loading promoted the increase of NiOCe in the catalyst and also increased the content of NiO. In order to further study the surface properties of xNiCe-800 catalyst, the strength of basic sites was determined by CO2-TPD method, as depicted in Fig. 16 . According to the surface basicity properties, the CO2 desorption peaks are divided into three parts, the weak basic sites α (100 °C), medium basic sites β (100–450 °C), and strong basic sites γ (above 450 °C). As Ni loading increases, the peak of α1 changed little, while the peak area of α2 gradually increased and shifted to high temperature that is similar to the results of Hao et al. [31] This indicates that the increase of Ni loading has little effect on the linear adsorption of CO2, but promotes the formation of more HCO3 − and HCO2 2− species on the surface. Distinctly, the β peaks shift to higher temperature and the peak area decreased gradually with increase Ni loading, indicating that Ni may cover the Ce-O site, which is not conducive to the formation of carbonate species and decreases the medium basic sites. Therefore, the 2NiCe-800 and 5NiCe-800 catalysts have fewer strong basic sites and more weak basic sites and medium basic sites, which greatly improved CO2 methanation activity. 3.2.4 CO2 methanation performance on different xNiCe-800 catalysts The CO2 hydrogenation activity of the xNiCe-800 catalysts with different Ni loading was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 17 . Similarly, all catalysts show that the CO2 conversion increases with increasing reaction temperature, and the activity of CO2 hydrogenation begins to decline and at about 400 °C. Only catalysts with Ni loading of 2 wt.% showed poor CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity in the tested temperature range, suggesting that abundant Ni sites are a key factor in increasing CO2 reaction activity. When Ni loading was increased, there was no significant difference in the activity at low temperature, while when the reaction temperature exceeds 350 °C, 5NiCe-800 catalyst performed best. At this time, the catalytic activity of xNiCe-800 catalysts is as follows: 5NiCe-800 > 10NiCe-800 > 15NiCe-800 > 2NiCe-800. From the above analysis, it is observed that the NiOCe interaction in Ni/CeO2 catalyst can be regulated by adjusting calcination temperature. More stable Ni-CeO2 interface is formed on the 5NiCe-800 catalyst, making more NiO species formed that are easily reduced and exposing a larger active area for H2 activation. In addition, there are more active oxygen vacancies on the Ni-CeO2 interface, which changes the distribution of basic sites on the catalyst surface. Generally, the medium basic sites and weak basic sites are favorable for the reaction. The effects of Ni loading and calcination temperature on the methanation activity of CO2 induced by Ni/CeO2 interaction were further analyzed. CO2 methanation on xNi/CeO2 calcined at 300 °C, 600 °C and 800 °C was evaluated and the results were shown in Fig. 18 . Obviously, the activity of xNi/CeO2 increases with reaction temperature rise and then declines after around 350 °C. Among these catalysts, the xNiCe-800 catalysts showed better CO2 activity. With the increase of Ni loading, the activity of xNiCe-T catalyst calcined at the same temperature increases first and then decreases with 5 wt.% Ni loading being the best. These results indicate that the Ni-based catalyst supported on rod-like CeO2 has a suitable metal-support interaction at 5 wt.% Ni loading and calcination temperature 800 °C. The long-term tests for 50 h were carried out for all Ni/CeO2 catalysts at 400 °C, as shown in Fig. 18(b). It is obvious that the catalyst showed excellent catalytic stability without deactivation during the test. 3.3 Study on CO2 methanation mechanism To further clarify the mechanism of CO2 methanation on NiCe catalyst, in-situ FTIR was carried out to observe the substances formed on the catalyst surface during CO2 hydrogenation reactions and their variation with temperature, as shown in Fig. 19 . Prior to measurement, all catalysts were reduced under reaction conditions and then passivated at 3 % O2/Ar. Therefore, after the sample is pressed into the operating chamber, it is reduced again at 350 °C for 30 min. Table 7 summarizes the main active surface substances and their corresponding wave number. Obviously, all catalysts exhibit infrared absorption characteristic peaks around 3734 cm−1, 3706 cm−1 and 3596 cm−1, which are attributed to type I, II-A and III OH groups, respectively [53]. It can be seen that the strength of hydroxyl group decreases with the increase of temperature, which means that the OH group on the catalyst surface can function as weak basic sites for CO2 chemisorption, which is consistent with the analysis results of CO2-TPD. For 2NiCe-800 catalyst, characteristic peaks of bicarbonate HCO3* (* indicates the adsorption site) were detected at 1210 cm−1, 1405 cm−1 and 1670 cm−1 at low temperatures of 30 °C and 50 °C. This is caused by the adsorption of CO2 on the OH site on the catalyst surface [49,54]. At the same time, the infrared absorption peak of bidentate carbonate (b-CO3*) appears at 1591 cm−1, which is attributed to the adsorption of CO2 on Ce3+ [31]. On the other hand, 1297 cm−1, 1508 cm−1 and 1558 cm−1 have monodentate carbonate species (m-CO3*) that are attributed to the adsorption of CO2 on Ce4+. At the same time, a weak peak attributed to the nickel carbonyl species appears at 2076 cm−1, which is caused by the adsorption of CO on Ni0 [49,55]. This peak occurs at 30 °C, which means that CO2 can dissociate at the Ni0 site, forming an active CO substance that is adsorbed on Ni0 surface. Meanwhile, at 30 °C, gaseous CO peaks appeared at 2177 cm−1 and 2106 cm−1, which further indicated that CO2 dissociation occurred on the catalyst surface. When the temperature rises to 200 °C, the infrared absorption peaks of HCO3* and b-CO3* disappear, while the infrared characteristic peaks of m-CO3* appear at 1508 cm−1 and 1458 cm−1, indicating the strong thermal stability of m-CO3*. This is consistent with the reported literature of b-CO3* instability in the presence of H2 [56]. The infrared absorption peaks attributed to the bidentate formate (b-HCOO*) were observed at 2846 cm−1, 1578 cm−1, 1371 cm−1 and 1328 cm−1, which may be formed by hydrogenation of HCO3* [31,48,49]. The acromion of the monodentate formate (m-HCOO*) was observed at 1610 cm−1, which was obtained by hydrogenation of m-CO3* on the catalyst surface [48]. According to the literature, m-HCO* species are more active than b-HCOO* species [48]. Therefor when the temperature rose to 250 °C, the m-HCOO* species disappeared, while the characteristic peak of b-HCOO* was further enhanced. At the same time, weak infrared absorption peak of CH4 was observed at 3015 cm−1 and 1305 cm−1, which was consistent with the activity evaluation results of the catalyst. When the further increase of temperature, the absorption peak intensity of HCOO* gradually decreased, while that of CH4 gradually increased, indicating that formats, as an intermediate species, participated in the formation process of CH4. Although no peak attributed to *CO was detected in the range of test temperature, gaseous CO peaks appeared at 2177 cm−1 and 2106 cm−1, especially when the temperature was greater than 300 °C, the intensity of gaseous CO peak increased with temperature increasing, indicating that a large amount of by-product CO was generated on the catalyst surface after 300 °C with CH4 selectivity decreased. Similarly, both catalysts 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 exhibit similar CO2 adsorption intermediates, as shown in Fig. 19(b) and (c). At 30–50 °C, the surface of the catalyst contains bicarbonate HCO3* (1210 cm−1, 1440 cm−1 and 1628 cm−1 on 5NiCe-600) (1210 cm−1, 1440 cm−1 and 1660 cm−1 on 5NiCe-800) and carbonate CO3* (1330 cm−1, 1558) cm−1 and (1583 cm−1) [54,55,57]. When the temperature rises to 200 °C, CO3* and HCO3* are hydrogenated to form b-HCOO* and m-HCOO*. At the same time, nickel carbonyl species on catalyst 5NiCe-600 were observed at 2055 cm−1 and 1929 cm−1, and nickel carbonyl species on catalyst 5NiCe-800 were observed at 2026 cm−1 and 1910 cm−1, indicating that there was adsorption of CO* on the catalyst surface, which may be derived from the dissociation of CO2 or the decomposition of formates [58]. With the increase of temperature, the HCOO* species gradually weakened, and the infrared absorption peak of CH4 appeared. Moreover, gaseous CO was detected by 5NiCe-800 catalyst at 2177 cm−1 and 2106 cm−1, indicating that the hydrogenation of HCO* to form CH4 was accompanied by the formation of CO, and few CO was formed on 5NiCe-600 catalyst. When the temperature continues to rise to about 400 °C, there is still a large amount of CO* on the surface of 5NiCe-600 catalyst without forming CO, and there is more adsorbed water and carbonate in the range of 1800–1200 cm−1. On the surface of 5NiCe-800 catalyst, strong peaks of m-CO3* (1355 cm−1 and 1340 cm−1) appeared, and no significant CO was produced, because at higher temperatures, the carbonate species formed by CO2 adsorption at the Ce4+ site were very stable and could not be further hydrogenated to form methane [59]. Overall, CO2 adsorption on different NiCe catalysts will form HCO3* and CO3* species, and these intermediates can be further hydrogenated to form HCOO*. As the reaction temperature rises, HCOO* hydrogenates to form the final product CH4, that is, HCOO* → CH4(g). The difference is that different NiCe catalysts have different adsorption capacities for CO*. The adsorption capacity of 2NiCe-800 catalyst for CO* is weak, and no obvious Ni (CO)n species is formed during the reaction, while 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 are more likely to adsorb CO* and form different nickel carbonyl species during the reaction, which leads to the difference in catalytic activity. Generally speaking, the Ni site can activate H2 molecules into H atoms, while CO2 mainly combines with metal-oxygen in the support to form carbonate and bicarbonate intermediates, and when the H atom and CO2 adsorption intermediates further react, the product CH4 is formed. For 2NiCe-800 catalyst, there are few active Ni sites on the catalyst surface, and the hydrogenation process of HCOO* species is limited, so m-HCOO with poor stability is decomposed into CO* [59], which directly forms gaseous CO with the increase of temperature, while b-HCOO with great stability is further hydrogenated to form CH4 [58,59]. The 5NiCe-600 and 5NiCe-800 catalysts have abundant Ni sites to activate H2 molecules and promote the further hydrogenation of HCOO* to form CH4. The difference between the two catalysts lies in the different stability of CO*. Obviously, CO* in 5NiCe-600 catalyst has always existed in the reaction process and hardly participated in the process of generating CH4, while CO* in 5NiCe-800 catalyst is relatively active and may be directly detached from the surface of the catalyst to form CO or participate in the process of hydrogenation to form CH4. So that the content of CO* is gradually reduced during the whole reaction process. Based on the in-situ FTIR analysis, the reaction mechanism of NiCe catalyst can be proposed. As mentioned above, CO2 is first adsorbed on the OH on the surface of the catalyst to form carbonate HCO3*, that is, CO2* + OH → HCO3*. At the same time, CO2 can be adsorbed on the Ce and oxygen vacancy on the surface of the support to form carbonate CO3*, that is, CO2* + O* → CO3*. H2 is activated to H atom on the surface of Ni [49], that is, H2 → H*. With the increase of temperature, H atoms can overflow from the Ni0 surface to the support [60]. Therefore, Ni-H can react with bicarbonates and carbonates to form formate species [49], that is, HCO3* + H → HCOO* and CO3* + H → HCOO*. Among them, the m-HCOO* formed by hydrogenation of m-CO3* is unstable and easily decomposed to form CO*. These CO* adsorbed on the surface of Ni0 to form nickel carbonyl species. Most HCOO* is converted directly to CH4 in the presence of hydrogen, that is, HCOO* → CH4(g). A part of the CO* obtained from the decomposition of HCOO* is directly desorbed from the catalyst surface to form gaseous CO or reacts with hydrogen to form CH4 under the action of H atoms. The results show that the final form of CO* is related to the richness of H* on the catalyst surface. CO(g) is formed on the surface of 2NiCe-800 catalyst with low Ni content, and can stably exist on the surface of 5NiCe-600 catalyst, and gaseous CH4 is formed on the surface of 5NiCe-800 catalyst with high Ni content. This further indicates that the CO2 methanation process requires the synergistic effect of Ni0 and the support. 4 Conclusion A series of Ni/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by using impregnation, and the structure-activity relationship was explored for CO2 methanation. The effects of the calcination temperature and Ni loading on catalyst structure and Ni/CeO2 interfacial properties were investigated. The results showed that changing the calcination temperature from 600 °C to 800 °C had little effect on the physical structure, but effectively enhanced MSI. 5NiCe catalyst calcined at 800 °C has more oxygen vacancy sites, better CO2 activation ability, good Ni dispersion and reducibility. CO2 methanation activity presents a volcano-shaped trend with Ni loading increase from 2 wt.% to 15 wt.% with the 5NiCe-800 being the best. Furthermore, there is a synergistic effect between Ni and CeO2 characterized by in-situ FTIR. Ni site is mainly used to activate H2 to H*. CO2 is first adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 to form HCO3* or CO3*, which are further hydrogenated to form the key intermediate HCOO*, and then HCOO* is hydrogenated to form CH4(g). CO2 methanation on the Ni/CeO2 catalysts mainly follow the formate reaction path. coredata.dc:description: CO2 methanation is an essential means of utilizing CO2, which is crucial to solving environmental problems and alleviating energy crisis. The design and development of high- performance low temperature CO2 methanation catalysts is the key to its further application. In this work, the metal-support interaction of Ni/CeO2 catalyst was regulated by changing the calcination temperature and Ni loadings to optimize the CO2 methanation performance. The results showed that 5NiCe-800 exhibited the best CO2 conversion of 83.1 % and 98.0 % CH4 selectivity at 350 °C, since it has a suitable Ni-CeO2 interaction, higher oxygen vacancy concentration, great reducibility and better basic site distribution. The reaction mechanism and the synergistic effect of CeO2 and Ni in CO2 methanation was revealed by in-situ FTIR, which is of great significance for the development of efficient CeO2 supported Ni-based for CO2 methanation.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced CO2 methanation activity over Ni/CeO2 catalyst by adjusting metal-support interactions
